greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Inverse of triangle S(n,m) defined by sequence A156290, n>=1, 1<=m<=n.
comment: This triangle S(n,m) appears as U_m(n) in the Knuth reference on p. 285. It is related to the Riordan triangle T_m(n) = A111125(n,m) by S(n,m) = A111125(n,m) - A111125(n-1,m), n>=m>=1 (identity on p. 286).
Also, S(n,m)-S(n-1,m) = A111125(n-1,m-1), n>=2, m>=1 (identity on p. 286).
These polynomials may be expressed in terms of the Faber polynomials of A263916 and are embedded in A127677 and A208513. - _Tom Copeland_, Nov 06 2015
link: D. E. Knuth, Johann Faulhaber and sums of powers, Math. Comp. 61 (1993), no. 203, 277-294.
formula: The n-th row o.g.f. is polynomial R(n,x) = 2/x*( T(n,(x + 2)/2) - 1 ), where T(n,x) is Chebyshev polynomial of the first kind. They form a divisibility sequence: if n divides m then R(n,x) divides R(m,x) in the ring Z[x].
mathematica: S[m_] := Flatten[Table[k/j Binomial[k + j - 1, 2 j - 1], {k, 1, m}, {j, 1, k}]]
xref: Same as triangle A208513 with the first column truncated.
results.author: _Hartmut F. W. Hoft_, Feb 07 2009
